qas.question: When was the release by Rhino Records of 78 rpm for jukebox owners?
What was the result of the use of this release of 78 rpm vinyl when used in vintage jukeboxes?
What was needed to successfully play the newer released 79 rpm vinyl?

answers.text: lightweight tone arms and jewel needles

qas.question: For whom was the 1990 release of 78 rpm intended?
How did the 1990 release of 78 rpm effect Rhino Records?

context: In the <a0_0>1990s<a0_0/> Rhino Records issued a series of boxed sets of 78 rpm reissues of early rock and roll hits, intended for <a3_0>owners of vintage jukeboxes<a3_0/>. This was a disaster because Rhino did not warn customers that their records were made of vinyl, and that the vintage 78 RPM juke boxes were designed with heavy tone arms and steel needles to play the hard shellac records of their time. This failure to warn customers gave the Rhino 78 records a <a4_0>bad reputation<a4_0/>,[citation needed] as <a1_0>they were destroyed<a1_0/> by old juke boxes and old record players but played very well on newer 78-capable turntables with modern <a2_0>lightweight tone arms and jewel needles<a2_0/>.
